pullRequest.body:
The nuclei form a heyting algebra and therefore a frame.
 
---

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,

### PR summary [a9eb5f28cd](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/21560/commits/a9eb5f28cd1a3fcc1a240b9edebeea21c1fb0edc)

#### Import changes for modified files

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ himp_apply`
`+ inf_apply`
`+ instance : HImp (Nucleus X)`
`+ instance : HeytingAlgebra (Nucleus X)`
`+ instance : Order.Frame (Nucleus X)`
`+ map_himp_apply`
`+ map_himp_le`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
I've pushed a small golf

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13257217933/job/37006035755)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13257217933/job/37006035909)

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

Thanks! ðŸš€

maintainer merge

Thanks! ðŸš€

maintainer merge

Thanks :tada:

bors merge
Why are you ungeneralising this definition?
I need the heyting implication in X to define the heyting implication on the nuclei. Should I ungeneralize later?
Yeah, with a `CompleteLattice` section and a `Frame` one
I tried to implement it, but I'm not really sure if it is correct
Ok, now I get want you wanted to do :)

```suggestion
@[simp] theorem inf_apply (m n : Nucleus X) (x : X) : (a âŠ“ b) x = a x âŠ“ b x := by
```
since you've started using those letters higher up in the file

```suggestion
  { toFun x := â¨… y â‰¥ x, a y â‡¨ b y
```

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
section CompleteLattice
```

```suggestion
section Frame
variable [Order.Frame X]
```
Can you make this a separate lemma? Does this generalise to something like `map_himp_apply (x y : X) : n (x â‡¨ n y) = x â‡¨ n y`?
Thats a nice one, that does work!
What do you think? You might want to use the lemmas in #21601

It semms like it shouldn't be true, because it is equivalent to: `n (sSup {w | w âŠ“ x â‰¤ n y}) â‰¤ n (sSup {w | w âŠ“ x â‰¤ y})` which looks like it should be false (but I failed to disprove it. I tried looking for counterexamples, but this lemma works for open and closed nuclei. I also failed to find a proof (while using the lemmas in your PR), so, long story short, I have no idea :-/

What about the linear order on three elements bot < mid < top? We have `x => y = if x <= y then top else y`. Then take `n bot = mid`, `n mid = mid`, `n top = top`. For `x = mid, y = bot`, we have `n (x => y) = n bot = mid` but `x => n y = top`

This is a nice coutnerexample! The heyting implications looks reasonable, the Nucleus satisfies his properties and the rest makes sense as well, so I guess we don't get this nice equality here after all.
In general, linear orders are a nice goto for counterexamples, because they are very unusual biheyting algebras with a very weird difference and implication
I think this can still be golfed. I'll try tomorrow
I shortened it a bit, but I didn't manage to get rid of the `have h` statement
I didn't make the proof shorter, but I made it easier to understand by using `calc`

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Order/Nucleus): nuclei form a frame
